title: phylogram: an R package for phylogenetic analysis with dendrograms
text: common application requiring conversion “phylo” “dendrogram” objects involves plotting tanglegrams visualize incongruence two phylogenetic trees. dendextend package (Galili 2015) features function tanglegram versatile plotting two distinct trees indicating discordant nodes using series non-parallel edges. However function currently support non-ultrametric “phylo” objects. example, two weighted neighbor-joining trees generated left right sections woodmouse alignment ape package (Paradis, Claude, Strimmer 2004), converted dendrograms visual comparison using dendextend::tanglegram.      Figure 2: Tanglegram showing incongruence left- right-hand sections woodmouse alignment.
code: library(ape) data(woodmouse) ## generate distance matrices for each section of the alignment dist1 <- dist.dna(woodmouse[, 1:482]) dist2 <- dist.dna(woodmouse[, 483:965]) ## build neighbor-joining trees phy1 <- nj(dist1) phy2 <- nj(dist2) ## root with No0912S as outgroup phy1 <- root(phy1, "No0912S") phy2 <- root(phy2, "No0912S") ## convert phylo objects to dendrograms dnd1 <- as.dendrogram(phy1) dnd2 <- as.dendrogram(phy2) ## rearrange in ladderized fashion dnd1 <- ladder(dnd1) dnd2 <- ladder(dnd2) ## plot the tanglegram dndlist <- dendextend::dendlist(dnd1, dnd2) dendextend::tanglegram(dndlist, fast = TRUE, margin_inner = 5)

Leaf nodes internal branching nodes can removed using function prune, identifies recursively deletes nodes based pattern matching “label” attributes. slower ape function drop.tip, offers benefits versatile string matching using regular expressions, ability remove inner nodes (extension subnodes) feature matching “label” attributes. aid visualization, function ladder rearranges tree, sorting nodes number members (analogous ladderize function ape package). Another function aiding tree visualization .cladogram, resets “height” attributes terminal leaf nodes zero progressively resets heights inner nodes single incremental units bottom-fashion. function reposition scales heights nodes tree given constant (passed via argument shift), features option reset node heights height farthest terminal leaf node root zero (specifying shift = "reset"). function remidpoint recursively corrects “midpoint”, “members” “leaf” attributes following manual editing tree converting nested list “dendrogram” object.

title: phylogram: an R package for phylogenetic analysis with dendrograms
text: simple three-leaf dendrogram Figure 1 can created manually follows: demonstrated , manually setting attributes dendrogram objects can rather tedious, motivating development functions automate generation manipulation tree structures. simple tree can recreated succinctly using phylogram package functions follows: Similarly, dendrogram objects can subset using either prune function standard list-subsetting syntax, help utility functions recursively reset node attributes. following code demonstrates one option rearranging tree species B sister taxa C ancestor:      Figure 3: Rearranged dendrogram species C ancestral B
code: x <- list(1, list(2, 3)) ## attach "leaf" and "label" attributes to leaf nodes attr(x[[1]], "leaf") <- TRUE attr(x[[2]][[1]], "leaf") <- attr(x[[2]][[2]], "leaf") <- TRUE attr(x[[1]], "label") <- "A" attr(x[[2]][[1]], "label") <- "B" attr(x[[2]][[2]], "label") <- "C" ## set "height" attributes for all nodes attr(x, "height") <- 2 attr(x[[1]], "height") <- 0 attr(x[[2]], "height") <- 1 attr(x[[2]][[1]], "height") <- attr(x[[2]][[2]], "height") <- 0 ## set "midpoints" attributes for all nodes attr(x, "midpoint") <- 0.75 attr(x[[1]], "midpoint") <- 0 attr(x[[2]], "midpoint") <- 0.5 attr(x[[2]][[1]], "midpoint") <- attr(x[[2]][[2]], "midpoint") <- 0 ## set "members" attributes for all nodes attr(x, "members") <- 3 attr(x[[1]], "members") <- 1 attr(x[[2]], "members") <- 2 attr(x[[2]][[1]], "members") <- attr(x[[2]][[2]], "members") <- 1 ## set class as "dendrogram"  ## Note that setting the class for the root node ## automatically sets the class of all nested subnodes class(x) <- "dendrogram" x #> 'dendrogram' with 2 branches and 3 members total, at height 2 x <- list(1, list(2, 3)) ## recursively set class, midpoint, members and leaf attributes x <- remidpoint(x) ## set incremental height attributes x <- as.cladogram(x) ## set label attributes using dendrapply set_label <- function(node){   if(is.leaf(node)) attr(node, "label") <- LETTERS[node]   return(node) } x <- dendrapply(x, set_label) x #> 'dendrogram' with 2 branches and 3 members total, at height 2 ## isolate root node (species C) ancestor <- prune(x, pattern = "C", keep = TRUE)  ## alternative option using subset operator ancestor <- x[[2]][[2]] ## create subtree without species C subtree <- prune(x, pattern = "C") ## graft subtree onto root x <- list(ancestor, subtree) ## set attributes as above x <- as.cladogram(remidpoint(x)) ## plot dendrogram plot(x, yaxt = "n")
